thread.title: Oregon latest state to ditch Obamacare co-op
thread.title_full: Oregon latest state to ditch Obamacare co-op | Washington Examiner

author: Robert King
title: Oregon latest state to ditch Obamacare co-op
text:
Oregon will become the eighth state to shut down its taxpayer-funded health insurance startup, the latest Obamacare co-op insurer to fold from financial troubles.
Health Republic Insurance, the state's co-op, said Friday it will not offer plans in 2016. Also on Friday, Colorado's co-op said that it would stop offering plans next year.
Oregon is the eighth state to close up its co-op out of the 23 that created one and the fourth in a week; one-third have announced they are closing.
Related Story: http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/article/2574118/ The co-op said Friday it priced its plans expecting to receive money from the federal government under its risk corridor program. That program was created under Obamacare to pay marketplace insurers for providing coverage for more older, sicker Americans.
  Bush gears up for the SEC primary in Tennessee Jeb Bush has a 57-person delegate team spread across each of Tennessee's nine congressional districts.
By Ryan Lovelace • 10/16/15 1:12 PM Insurers requested more than $2 billion in payments but the government provided only $362 million.
The shortfall for Oregon placed the co-op in a "difficult financial position," it said.
The effect of that shortfall is being felt now as several other co-ops have announced their closure for the same reason.
The co-op program was created to offer more competition for Obamacare enrollees.
Oregon's co-op served nearly 15,000 members, and will still give coverage through the end of the year.
Also from the Washington Examiner Judge strikes Arizona law restricting medication abortions State court says legislature overstepped its authority in passing the measure three years ago.
By Paige Winfield Cunningham • 10/16/15 1:11 PM Top Story Cummings blasts Republicans over Huma Abedin interview Cummings said he hoped the committee's work would not be subject to more "very targeted leaks."
By Sarah Westwood • 10/16/15 12:13 PM
